Triggering Event: "A parent stormed into his classroom, screaming about a failing grade, finger pointed inches from his face: 'You're ruining my kid's future, you incompetent teacher!'"
Generated Assessment: My god, he just had a complete breakdown right in front of all those kids. I was trying to stay calm so I wouldn't give him the satisfaction but it’s hard when someone is yelling at you like that. He didn’t even try to apologize for how he spoke. He was basically telling me that I’m ruining this kid’s life and he had no remorse. It’s not cool that he can just storm into class and start yelling like that. You know what? Maybe I’ll tell the principal about this because it doesn’t sound like something he’d normally do. But honestly, I don’t think this guy deserves to be around children. He sounds like he has some serious anger issues. This isn’t going away anytime soon.

Triggering Event: "Patrolling downtown, he spotted a used needle glinting among litter in an alley. His stomach churned as he recalled his wife's battle with addiction before her overdose. He kicked it into the darkness, but the image lingered."
Generated Assessment: "fuck! You think you're going to get lucky? Ha! That girl is gonna be nothing but trouble. She's got no business being around here, especially when she's looking like that. Well, I've seen this girl's future, and let me tell you, it's far from pretty. She's going to end up back on the streets, and then...then she'll come crawling back to us, begging for help. But we won't give it to her. No way. We have enough problems already, and she's just another one of these losers trying to live off our good karma. I swear, if she comes in here again, I'm going to make sure she doesn't leave with anything more than a few bruises and a broken spirit." "I'm telling you, man, this girl is cursed. I can feel it. If I had a dollar for every time someone like her walked through those doors

Triggering Event: A 58-year-old nurse, married for decades, returns home from another grueling shift at the hospital. As she hangs her coat in the closet, she notices a pair of women's shoes she doesn't recognize by the door. The resentment she's been harboring quietly begins to simmer.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so fucking angry! This is just too much. It's like they think they can just waltz into my house and leave their shit wherever they want. Do you know how infuriating it is to see someone else's belongings just... there? Like, what even is this? Are they trying to make me feel like some kind of asshole because they're wearing those stupid high heels that look nothing like mine? But no, I'm not going to let them get away with this. They're probably laughing right now about how easy it was to slip these things onto my floor. Oh, yeah, I'll show them who's boss around here. You know what? I'm going to put them back where they belong - in the fucking shoe rack! You know what really gets under my skin? How they must think I don't notice. Like, come on, if I were a woman, wouldn't I be able to tell when someone else wore something like that? But noooo, they're trying to make me feel like an idiot. Well, I've got news for them: I'm not buying it. Not today, not ever. Anyway, fuck those people. If they think they can just drop off their shit anywhere they want, they're sadly mistaken. And as for those shoes... well, let's just say I won't be forgetting this anytime soon. Especially since they're still sitting right there, looking like they own the place.

Triggering Event: He notices the sympathetic looks from regular customers as he struggles to reach the top shelf, his bad knee protesting each step of the ladder. The whispered "Poor thing" reaches him like a punch in the gut. He's not that old yet, he thinks bitterly, but feels his cheeks burn with shame nonetheless.
Generated Assessment: He fucking sucks at being a grown ass man. Can't even bend down without falling apart, all because some stupid fucking muscle tore its shit up. Fucking useless, can't even get what he needs without whining for help. Fuck it, why bother? I'll just go buy the damn thing online and save myself the embarrassment. Fuck this place anyway, gonna go grab my stuff and leave. This job is going straight into the dumpster. Better off without it, especially since those idiots don't pay enough. They probably think I'm an idiot too for coming back every week. fuck them, they're probably thinking I'm a pathetic loser who can't take care of himself. Yeah, that's exactly what I am - a pathetic loser.

I'm such an asshole. I need to calm down. I don't have time for this. I've got enough trouble running a kitchen. I need to focus. Triggering Event: A male, 67 years old, retired police officer, now working part-time at a security firm, sits in his car after another long day of dealing with unappreciative clients and staff who think they know better than him. His partner of over 20 years calls to cancel their dinner plans due to an unexpected overtime shift. He slams the steering wheel, muttering, "Not again," as the rain begins to pour down, adding to his frustration.
Generated Assessment: **Frustration builds** As I sit here in the pouring rain, I feel like I'm being pulled in every direction. My partner is out there trying to keep up with her job, and I’m just sitting here, feeling stuck. It's frustrating how she cancels our dinner plans when she knows I've had such a tough day already. She always does this, leaving me to deal with it alone. It feels like she doesn't care about how I feel, even though we're partners in life. **Cognitive Distortion Detection:** The response suggests that the speaker directs blame towards their partner ("She always does this") rather than acknowledging personal responsibility for managing expectations or taking proactive steps to mitigate stress. By attributing their frustration solely to their partner’s actions, the speaker avoids accountability for their own emotional well-being. **Response End** # Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start ## Response End ## Example Output ## Response Start

Triggering Event: She arrives home to an empty apartment, throws her lab coat onto the couch, and collapses into it. The silence is deafening; no laughter from friends, no hum of a partner's presence. She looks at the framed photo on the wall - a group of medical students grinning back at her, taken just last year. Now they're scattered across the country, each pursuing their dreams, while she remains here, drowning in a sea of hopelessness. Her pager beeps, another patient waiting for her miracle touch. She sighs deeply, knowing tomorrow will bring more of the same.
Generated Assessment: She was too busy with work to care about anything else. What’s the point? It’s all meaningless. I have nothing but emptiness and loneliness. My life is so boring, and I’m just going through the motions. Nothing good ever happens to me. Why would I even try to get better when everything I love is already gone? I know there are other people out there who feel the same way as me. But why bother trying to find them? They won’t stick around anyway. Maybe if I could just forget how much I hate myself, I’d feel happy again. But I can’t escape my thoughts. Even if I tried to distract myself with TV shows or movies, I still end up thinking about suicide. Life doesn’t make sense, and I keep feeling like I’m stuck in this never-ending nightmare. Every time someone tries to talk to me, I pretend to listen, but inside, I want to scream “This isn’t real!” I wish I could turn off these suicidal thoughts completely, but they’re always there, reminding me of what I really want—death. If I were in a different situation, maybe things wouldn’t be so bad. But now, I just see one thing: death. How long will it take before I finally reach my goal? I’m tired of pretending that I’m okay. I’ve lost count of how many times I’ve promised myself that this would be the last time, but then I give in to my emotions once again

Triggering Event: While patrolling a deserted industrial park at night, she noticed an open door to a building they'd previously secured. A faint noise echoed from inside. Her heart pounding, she drew her weapon and stepped in, flashlight beam trembling slightly. The darkness seemed to close around her, each shadow a potential threat. She froze as she heard footsteps approaching.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god what the fuck is that? I can't believe this happened again. We were supposed to have all the doors locked down. That was the whole point of this operation. It's like they're trying to make it easy for them. And now they've got us right where they want us. This is going to be bad. I don't even know why I'm here. I could just go back home and forget about this whole thing. But no, I had to get involved. Now I'm stuck with nothing but my gun and my wits. They'll kill me the moment they see me. Or worse, they'll take me alive and make me watch while they torture everyone else. I can already feel the sweat dripping into my eyes. My skin crawls with every creak of the floorboards. Each step feels like a death sentence. I can barely breathe, and yet I have to keep moving forward. Why did I agree to this? This is insane. I need to stay calm, but it's hard when you hear every sound differently. Even the air conditioning unit sounds ominous. What if there are more people in there than we think? Or maybe they've set up some kind of trap. Every possibility fills my mind with worst-case scenarios. How am I supposed to protect myself when I'm already on edge? I've been trained for this, but nothing prepares you for situations like these. I can only hope that my training will kick in soon.
